Materials with high performance and selectivity over other gases, requiring low energy demand, are being developed for large-scale deployment. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a proven technology for gas separation in various industrial applications. MOFs have a virtually unlimited number of crystal combinations in their highly porous lattice, making them a potential solution for CO2 capture from the atmosphere or industrial sources. Although MOFs have complex crystal structures that are difficult to represent in tabular data formats using conventional machine learning (ML) methods or deep learning, graph neural networks (GNNs) can easily be trained on their crystallographic information files (CIFs).

In this work, we train GNNs to create an end-to-end workflow to screen a large number of MOF crystal structures directly from CIFs for their CO2 working capacity or CO2/N2 selectivity under low-pressure conditions. Our preliminary results show that a simple 2-layered graph convolutional network (GCN) can achieve an R2 score in the range of 0.87 to 0.89.

Carbon dioxide (CO2) capture, utilization, and sequestration (CCUS) is crucial for limiting global warming to 1.5°C. To achieve this goal, we need to deploy CO2 capture capabilities at a gigaton capacity, approximately 150 times the current capacity by 2050 (Global CCS Institute, 2020). Currently, CO2 capture using chemical solvents is the most mature technology, but it has large footprints and high energy demands. Studies suggest that implementing aqueous amine-based CO2 capture can reduce the energy efficiency of a coal-fired power plant by 20-30% (Oko et al., 2017). The use of thermal energy for solvent regeneration accounts for 20-25% of the operating cost, and solvent-based capture systems are expensive to build due to the large footprint of packed bed towers.

New separation technologies using solid sorbents, membranes, or cryogenics are being developed to address the need for new material development to improve CO2 capture capacity, selectivity over other gases, and reduce regeneration energy demand. There is an urgent need to develop energy-efficient and compact capture processes to allow widespread adoption of CCUS in the industrial sector and reduce global warming.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are being investigated for their CO2 adsorption capacity, CO2 selectivity, stability, and regeneration capacity to efficiently remove CO2 from point sources. MOFs have promising properties due to their high CO2 adsorption capacities, which are inherently tunable through their structural features (Sumida et al., 2012; Li et al., 2022). MOFs are built from transition metal clusters and organic linkers into structural building units (SBUs) that are extended into well-defined, uniform structures with high surface area and structural stability. The highly tunable SBUs in MOFs offer exceptional adaptability in isoreticular manipulation and controllable functionalities in CO2 adsorption.

For post-combustion CO2 capture processes, there is a need to understand the role of impurities, particularly water, and their impact on the stability of the sorbents and energy requirement for regeneration processes. However, only a small number of MOFs have been studied experimentally to meet target-specific requirements, highlighting the need for a faster and reliable way to design and screen MOFs for post-combustion CO2 capture.
